DESCRIPTION: The German V2 missile is the first man-made object to reach an altitude above 100 km (176 km), which is the limit between the atmosphere and space according to the International Aeronautical Federation.
The small Soviet satellite Sputnik 1 becomes the first object satellited by man.

The Russian dog Laika, the first living animal to orbit in space[1], who died after a few hours aboard Sputnik 2. She is therefore, at the same time, the first living being to die in space. space, and remains to this day the only death recorded above the Kármán Line.
America enters the race for space conquest by launching its first Explorer 1 satellite.
Creation of NASA, the United States space agency.
The Soviet probe Luna 1 makes the first flyby of the Moon and becomes the first artificial object in heliocentric orbit.
Luna 2: first spacecraft to make contact with another celestial body (the Moon).
Luna 3 reveals to the world the first images of the hidden side of the Moon.
First hominid sent into space for an orbital flight, the chimpanzee Ham, during the Mercury-Redstone 2 mission.
First human sent into space for an orbital flight, the Soviet Yuri Gagarin, during the Vostok 1 mission.

Alan Shepard becomes the first American in space (suborbital flight) during the Mercury-Redstone 3 mission. First manned space mission that landed with a pilot still in the spacecraft, therefore the first complete manned space flight according to the definitions of the FAI[2].

Aged 25 at the time, the Russian Guerman Titov was until July 20, 2021 the youngest person to have gone into space, during the Vostok 2 mission. And still remains to this day, the youngest person to have made an orbital flight.
First American manned orbital flight. John Glenn becomes the first American in Earth orbit aboard his Friendship 7 capsule during the Mercury-Atlas 6 mission.
First British satellite Ariel 1 (launched from Cape Canaveral). The United Kingdom becomes the third country to have a satellite in orbit after the USSR and the United States.
First Canadian satellite, Alouette 1 (launched by an American rocket). Canada becomes the fourth country to have a satellite in orbit, after the USSR, the United States and the United Kingdom.
First flyby of another planet. First flyby of Venus with Mariner 2.
First woman in space, Valentina Tereshkova. She also remains to this day the only one to have flown solo.
First launch of a lithergol rocket, with solid fuel and a liquid oxidizer, LEX, from the Île du Levant.
First Italian satellite, San Marco 1 (launched by the Americans). Italy thus becomes the first nation in Western Europe to have a satellite in orbit, and the fifth in the world.
First spacewalk by Soviet Alexei Leonov aboard the Voskhod 2 capsule.
First flyby of the planet Mars and first images of the Martian surface thanks to the Mariner 4 probe.
France launches its first satellite, Asterix, from a Diamant rocket, thus becoming the third world space power.
First space meeting between the Gemini 6 and Gemini 7 spacecraft.
First soft landing on another celestial body. The Soviet Luna 9 probe lands gently on the Moon.
First orbit around the Moon. Luna 10 successfully placed itself in orbit of the Moon.
First space docking between the Gemini 8 spacecraft and the Agena target rocket, carried out by astronaut Neil Armstrong.
First sounding rocket launch from Antarctica, a Dragon rocket from the Dumont-d'Urville Antarctic Base.
First probe into the atmosphere of another planet. First human object on the surface of another planet. (Venus)Venera 4 sends data from the atmosphere up to 25 km above Venus, before losing contact.

First Australian satellite WRESAT-1 (launched by the Americans from a British Woomera Rocket Range base but on Australian soil). This launch base will have been used for the first British tests and the development of the first European launcher Europa.
First living beings to fly over the Moon, turtles, aboard the Soviet Zond 5 lunar mission. First manned spacecraft to fly over the Moon.
First time that a crew escapes from Earth orbit and enters lunar orbit. First time a human saw an Earthrise, during the Apollo 8 mission.
First space shuttle to reach and return, BOR-2, which would be used in the development of the Soviet Buran shuttle program.
Man's first steps on the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission, taken by Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin. It is the furthest point on Earth ever traveled by a human, or even a living being known to date.
Launch of the first Japanese satellite: Ōsumi. Japan becomes the fourth space power to successfully launch into orbit on its own after the USSR, the United States and France.
China becomes the fifth space power after the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Japan to successfully launch into orbit
Lunokhod 1: first rover robot to land on extra-terrestrial ground (the Moon).
First successful landing on another planet (Venus). Venera 7 lands on the surface of Venus and maintains contact for 27 minutes.
Launch of the first manned space station, Salyut-1, by the Soviet Union.
The use of the lunar rover in the Apollo 15 mission was an additional technological challenge
Successful orbiting of the British satellite Prospero France, Japan and China.
First orbit around another planet, Mars, of the Mariner-9 probe.
First successful soft landing on Mars, by the Soviet Mars 3 probe. But it shuts down a few seconds after confirmation of success.
Apollo 17, last lunar mission in the Apollo program.
Launch of the American Skylab space station. The United States becomes the second to have an autonomous space station.
First flyby of Jupiter by the Pioneer 10 probe.
First flyby of Mercury by the American Mariner 10 probe.
Creation of ESA, the European Space Agency, official transfer of launch activities to Kourou, French Guiana.
First successful landing on Venus. The Soviet Venera 9 probe retransmits the first photographs taken from the surface of another planet (Venus). First probe in orbit of Venus.
First operational mission to the surface of Mars. Viking-1 becomes the first operational probe to land on Mars. First image of Martian soil.
Vladimír Remek becomes the first neither American nor Soviet astronaut. He flies aboard Soyuz 28.
First flyby of Saturn by the Pioneer 11 probe.
First Indian satellite Rohini 1B launched by an Indian SLV-3 rocket from the Satish-Dhawan space center. India becomes the seventh space power.
First takeoff of the space shuttle (Columbia).
Successful launch of the first European Meteosat-2 satellite, launched by a European Ariane 1 rocket.
First West European and first Frenchman in space, Jean-Loup Chrétien. He is also the first astronaut from the Western bloc to fly aboard Soyuz, and aboard a Soviet station.
1000th orbital flight of a Soyuz rocket, a first in the history of launchers.
First machine to fly in the atmosphere of another planet. Vega 1 releases sounding balloons into the atmosphere of Venus.
First flyby of Uranus by Voyager 2
Placement of the first element of the Soviet Mir orbital station into orbit. First modular space station.
First flyby of a comet. Soviet Vega 1 probe flies past Halley's Comet
First Israeli Ofek-1 satellite launched by an Israeli Shavit rocket. Israel becomes the eighth space power.
First flight of the Soviet space shuttle Buran, first flight of a space shuttle in automatic mode.
First flyby of Neptune by Voyager 2.
Launch of the Hubble space telescope, holding the longevity record for a space telescope in 2022.
First satellite to orbit Jupiter: Galilleo
First Martian rover. The Mars Pathfinder probe lands on Mars, releasing the mobile robot Sojourner.
The first module of the International Space Station (ISS) is installed. This is Zarya, a Russian module.
Start of permanent human presence in space, aboard the ISS.
Deliberate destruction of the Mir station, which is precipitated into the atmosphere and burns up there.
Dennis Tito, first space tourist.
China's first manned space flight by Yang Liwei with the Shenzhou 5 capsule
First non-governmental manned suborbital flight as part of the Ansari X Prize with SpaceShipOne. The latter was won on October 4, 2004 during the second flight [3].
First satellite to orbit Saturn: Cassini.
The European Huygens probe lands on Titan. It is the most distant object to date to have landed on the ground of a star.
Launch of the largest cargo ship to date, the ATV.
First Iranian orbital flight, thanks to the Safir launcher. Iran becomes the 9th space power.
First asteroid sample return. The Hayabusa probe reenters the Earth's atmosphere after a round trip to the asteroid Itokawa.
First orbit around Mercury, by the MESSENGER probe. It is the second probe to fly over the planet after Mariner 10 40 years before, which demonstrates the difficulty of reaching this planet.
Final takeoff of the space shuttle Atlantis, ending the American space shuttle program.
First Chinese space station, Tiangong 1. China becomes the third nation to independently own a space station.

Voyager 1 is the first probe to cross the heliopause and the first artifact to penetrate the interstellar medium by leaving the heliosphere. It is the most distant object of terrestrial origin to date, drifting in outer space more than 20 billion kilometers from Earth.
First North Korean orbital flight, with the successful launch of Unha, North Korea becomes the 10th space power.
First South Korean orbital flight, with the successful launch of KSLV-1, South Korea becomes the 11th space power.
First landing on a comet. The European space probe Rosetta is placed in orbit around the comet Tchouri and sends a small lander, Philae, to analyze the composition of its soil and its structure.
First flyby of Pluto by the New Horizons probe. Last original encounter with one of the nine major planets recognized in 1981.
First vertical landing of a space rocket, by Blue Origin with its New Shepard. Other rockets were capable of a powered landing, but none had the ability to cross the Karman Line (100 km altitude).
First vertical landing of an orbital rocket, the Falcon 9.
First flyby of a Kuiper Belt object, by the New Horizons probe.
First landing on the far side of the Moon, by the Chinese Chang'e 4 lander.
First Israeli lunar lander (Beresheet) to reach lunar orbit (launched by a private American Falcon 9 rocket), but fails to land smoothly and crashes on the Moon.
First Indian lunar lander, Chandrayaan-2, which will crash.
Shortest interval between two launches of the same rocket, two Kuaizhou-1As left 6 hours apart.
The Russian spacecraft Progress MS-14 breaks the record for time from launch to docking with the ISS, now set at 03:20 and 14 seconds.

First manned space flight operated by a private company. The private company SpaceX sends, using their Falcon 9 rocket and their Crew Dragon capsule, 2 astronauts to join the ISS Space Station for the DM-2 mission.
Successful orbiting (by a Japanese H-IIA rocket) of the Al Amal probe around Mars. The United Arab Emirates becomes the seventh to have a space probe to another planet.

First powered aerodynamic flight on another planet and first aerodyne-type aerobot (and hovercraft). First takeoff from the ground of another planet. That is to say, first aircraft to use aerodynamic force to fly on another planet. Ingenuity successfully carries out an aerodynamic flight on Mars. Symbolically, Ingenuity carries with it a piece of canvas from the Wright brothers' plane.

Production of oxygen on another planet: a crucial first for the conquest of space. After landing gently on Mars on February 18, 2021, the Perseverance rover via its MOXIE instrument transformed carbon dioxide from the atmosphere Martian in oxygen.

Putting the first module (Tianhe: central module) of the Chinese Space Station (CSS) into orbit. This new station is historically the third modular station after Mir and ISS. China becomes the second nation to have an autonomous modular space station.

First non-American operational mission on Martian soil (Mars 3 was not operational). First non-American Mars rover. China successfully lands the Zhurong rover on Mars for the Tianwen-1 mission, becoming the third country to soft-land a probe on the planet.

Billionaire Richard Branson becomes the first person to reach space, following the American standard (considering the space boundary to be 50 miles, but below the Kármán Line), using a machine developed by the company he founded himself, reaching the altitude of 86.1 km aboard the VSS Unity.

First manned flight of the New Shepard rocket. On board, billionaire Jeff Bezos becomes the first person to cross the Kármán Line, following the International standard (considering the space boundary at 100 km), using a machine developed by the company that he himself founded, reaching an altitude of 106 km. Through this same suborbital flight, the Dutchman Oliver Daemen (18 years old) became the first minor and the youngest person to reach space.
First entirely tourist orbital flight, Inspiration4 mission which is also the third operational manned mission of Crew Dragon.

First film shot for cinema in space. Klim Chipenko, director, and Ioulia Peressild, actress, take off aboard the Soyuz MS-19 mission to the International Space Station. First tourist mission to the ISS with two tourists.
William Shatner at 90 years old, becomes the oldest human to travel above the Kármán line, aboard the New Shepard rocket for the NS-18 mission.
Parker Solar Probe becomes the first object to penetrate the Sun's atmosphere.[4]

Launch of the James Webb Space Telescope from Guyana aboard an Ariane 5. JWST, the largest space telescope, designed by NASA's collaboration of ESA and CSA, is the most expensive scientific space probe of history[5].
